subject: Change "operation" argument type in CynaraAdminPolicy constructor
commitMessage:
Change "operation" argument type in CynaraAdminPolicy constructor

This change is needed in for policy updates. We need to support wide spectrum
of results, starting from DENY (0) to ALLOW (0xFFFF). SM should not be limited
to few enum class literals.

Change-Id: I1e8d26893120309f6d6276da4bb5e146936a7e59
Signed-off-by: Marcin Lis <m.lis@samsung.com>

commitMessage:
Add constructor to CynaraAdminPolicy struct: taking elements from base structure

elements of the base structure.

subject: Fix assertion about not clearing DataCommands objects
commitMessage:
Fix assertion about not clearing DataCommands objects

The following assertion occurs during exiting security-manager
when any command was executed on security-manager db:
"Condition: m_dataCommandsCount == 0 All stored procedures must be
deleted before disconnecting SqlConnection"
It was caused by not clearing list of DataCommands before destroying db
SqlConnection.

Change-Id: If2151dfc38df23ce9af00a47ac0d7939c13adaa1
Signed-off-by: Sebastian Grabowski <s.grabowski@samsung.com>

subject: Increase debugging information level for DEBUG build types
commitMessage:
Increase debugging information level for DEBUG build types

Added "-g3 -ggdb3" flags for DEBUG build types.
From gcc man pages:
Level 3 includes extra information, such as all the macro definitions
present in the program.

Change-Id: I879c241e5eef4ed31129df785ea27d51e2689e16
Signed-off-by: Sebastian Grabowski <s.grabowski@samsung.com>

comments.message: Patch Set 2: Patch Set 1 was rebased

Patch Set 2:

Are You sure that we need this extra debug symbols? Maybe it would be better to add new build flag that enables them?

Patch Set 2:

Well, if we use defines in our code this may be helpful. I am not so sure having another build flag is a good option i.e.: it would depend on the debugging case.

Patch Set 2:

Actually, I meant new build type which would add this compile options (like "build_type DEBUG").

Patch Set 2:

I think it is good to have as much information as it is only possible when debugging and what would give having another build_type if someone would have a choice of having more or less debugging information? Then probably one of the options would be useless...

Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

Ok, I am ok with this. I am not stopping it. Let the maintainer decide :)

subject: Removed timeout for poll.
commitMessage:
Removed timeout for poll.

Security-server in many cases may need much more time than just 2s to
accomplish given client request. It seems to be reasonable to just
remove the timeout by changing it to be infinite.

Change-Id: Iae8074b3bb5bfa134fd6dc324907ad3bba6f3b9b
Signed-off-by: Sebastian Grabowski <s.grabowski@samsung.com>

comments.message:
Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

I think that the assumption that the server may need more time is correct, but the solution is not.

1. The same timeout value is used when connecting and sending data to the server. We should avoid the situation when client app hangs forever while trying to connect or send something.

2. You should provide some condition when the current timeout is not working correctly, tell us how to reproduce it and how to test Your change.

3. Using non-blocking sockets and setting an infinite timeout is a little bit ambiguous :).

Patch Set 1:

ad.1) I'll take a look at that.
ad.2) timeout occurs i.e.: in patches for user type policy reloading (https://review.tizen.org/gerrit/#/c/31299/) then you may test it by running: security-manager-cmd -r
ad.3) why do you think it is ambiguous? Do you also think that setting any timeout for sockets in poll is ambiguous? If not, what is the limit? ;-)

Patch Set 1:

ad.2)
I will take a look on the policy reloading process. I think that reloading four profiles with 60 privileges in each one should not take so much time. 2 seconds is just too much for this operation...
ad.3)
Actually I meant that using non-blocking sockets together with blocking of the whole client thread without timeout is ambiguous. Isn't it? "Block, or not to block - that is the question" :). Timeout is necessary here and it should be adjusted to let SM handle its work.

Patch Set 1:

ad.2) ...but it is just one of the cases. It would be nice to have it all working faster.
ad.3) yes, but non-blocking sockets with zero timeout here is not the case.

Patch Set 1:

By "no timeout" I actually meant an infinite timeout. Sorry for not being clear.

Patch Set 1:

We could introduce some time limits... i.e.: per type of a request... hmm.. what do you think? And more, what the limits should be? I am not sure if we can answer those questions now (this is why infinite was chosen).
ad.1) with connect case it seems like not having any special timeout for it should not make any harm: i.e.: when security-manager service is stopped its socket is in listen state so connect succeeds. It would also be good if someone knowing systemd took a look at it.

Patch Set 1:

I agree that we cannot predict necessary timeouts. It is to early for that. We need to test at least some preliminary version of SM with policy reloading, updating, setting and listing and gather the info about performance. Then we will be able to judge whether to change timeouts or to optimize algorithms.

As for connection on socket from systemd - indeed, setting timeouts seems to have no effect, but only in the case when the service hasn't been started yet (systemd listening on socket).

subject: Implement master and slave mode
commitMessage:
Implement master and slave mode

Final patch with master and slave mode implementation. Since every container
will have its own privilege database, master mode will handle only SMACK/Cynara
calls.

[Verification]  Build, install, run with containers active in the system and
                run tests inside container. All tests (except tc02, which
                verifies Cynara labels) should pass as they did.

Change-Id: Ibd1d884ad7dba6a15ebaa068c2c216a88562eb50

subject: Fix potential buffer overflow error CID: 40674
commitMessage:
Fix potential buffer overflow error CID: 40674

Change backported from security-server repository.

Change-Id: Ifcbd8ebe4ddfa4c04dd000639cab2c60648c3943
Signed-off-by: Rafal Krypa <r.krypa@samsung.com>

subject: Prepare security-manager for master-slave mode
commitMessage:
Prepare security-manager for master-slave mode

This commit prepares security-manager for work in master/slave mode.
In order to properly install/uninstall applications inside containers,
security-manager inside container (slave) must delegate calls related to
Cynara/SMACK to security-manager outside a container (master).
Since entire master/slave mode is a huge change, it is divided into two
commits - this is the first one. Logic for master service and changes in
service to work as slave are left for second commit.

With this change security-manager launched without additional arguments should
work as it did.

Change-Id: If05cdeb2d2c35c046bf4cb46d884a3689dab57ad

subject: Extract communication functions to common library
commitMessage:
Extract communication functions to common library

Since slave service will use the same functions as client library to send data,
these are extracted in this commit and will be used in the next change.

[Verification]  Build, install, run tests.

Change-Id: I4b9e11015c657066657f493e87d68958283bb947

subject: Extract BaseService from Service class
commitMessage:
Extract BaseService from Service class

BaseService will be a base class for SM services, eg. a master service coming
up in next patches.

[Verification]  Build, install, run tests.

Change-Id: Ie55d1b22c8887ee605e16b86adee75cfffdbe147
